this is a small script to test this feature, it work very well for me, assuming that the stopped node has no ID according to libvirt documentation

from libcloud.compute.types import Provider
from libcloud.compute.providers import get_driver 

def start_libvirt_node(name):
    Driver = get_driver(Provider.LIBVIRT)
    conn = Driver(uri='qemu:///system')
    response = conn.ex_start(name)
    if response==True : 
        return 'node started'
    else :
        return 'node not started'

Also, I should note that this has currently only been fully tested with Python 2.7.  It's likely that some minor adjustments will need to be made for Python 3.X (and maybe 2.5 if 2.5 support isn't officially dropped before this is merged in).

I've glanced over the code and posted some comments in-line. There are some issues, but it shouldn't be too hard to address those:
- Making sure it works with all the supported Python versions (after you add the tests it should be easier to test that using `tox`)
- Some code readability can be improved by making the code more flat and reducing the levels of nesting (either by using multiple list comprehensions or by splitting code in multiple functions)

As far as the high level stuff goes - overall all the class relationships and driver look solid.
QueryResult class rewritten to return generator. Please review.
@galet Thanks - I've added some comments :)

Thanks Kami for your comments. I will push an update soon.

Just a question: It could be written also as an iterator. This would simplify use cases when you just need the first item.
Example:

``` python
res = ex_query(...)
first_record = res.iterate_records().next()
```

vs.

``` python
res = ex_query(...)
first_record = res.next()
```

Any reason to prefer generator?

@galet Yeah, you can implement `next` method (and `__next__` since we also support Python 3). This way you can call `.next()` on it directly.

E.g. https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/storage/drivers/cloudfiles.py#L856

@wrigri Spotted a couple of minor things, otherwise looks good.

Should be ready to be merged once you finish the tests.

I see. Should we support both ways?

If so, what should be the correct behavior for:

``` python
res = ex_query(...)
res.next()
res.iterate_records().next()
res.next()
```

?

Should the generator start always from the beginning?

Other than that, the code should all be PEP8 compliant (except for some long lines due to long method names in test_gce.py), and epydoc doesn't show any errors (except that it complains about 'inherits').

@joemiller Yeah, sorry, I've meant 0.13.x (I've also updated my comment) :)
I thought we were on the whole against having a CLI as part of libcloud? A CLI is just noise for people using libcloud as a lib?

@Jc2k Yeah, I do believe an actual CLI for managing all the libcloud resources should be available as a separate (optional) package. Actual management CLI would probably also depend on more libraries (probably `cliff` which has tons of dependencies by itself) and have different versions requirements.

`update-pricing` command is a bit special case though. I would imagine a lot of people using just the library would also like to use this command.

@Kami I still disagree about `libcloud update-pricing`.

If I was writing a Django app that needed this data, I would write a celery task to update the pricing routinely.

If I was writing a command line tool, I would build the update pricing call into it. I wouldn't want the users to have to call `libcloud update-pricing` manually.

Even if I was writing a hacky script that needed to use pricing data I would probably want to make sure it was always up to date whenever I ran that script. So I would want to use the API.

For prototypers and tinkerers we could just use use the "run module" style - `python -m libcloud.pricing`. That would seem more appropriate?

First a quick recap to make sure everyone is one the same page and aware what is the end goal / desired output:
1. We want to allow users to use a custom pricing file without modifying any code (I think default to `~/.libcloud/pricing.json file if available is a good and straight-forward approach)
2. Provide a simple mechanism to update the pricing file - it's still up to the user to reload the pricing file / invalidate the cache if they use libcloud in a long running process

@Jc2k I do agree about the "pricing always up to date in my app / script" part - we need to provide programmatic API which users can call when they run their script or initialize the app.

As far as the celery goes - I personally think it's an overkill for a thing like this. If a CLI / "run module" style is available you can simply use a cron job.

As far as the "run module" style goes - I'm not to opinionated about this, although I'm not a big fun of `python -m libcloud.pricing` since it's less explicit than `libcloud update-pricing`.

I would like to hear more opinion on this one.
P.S. @Jc2k - thanks for your feedback so far!

No problem!

My feedback so far has been from the angle of "Libcloud is a library". I find it weird that a library would have a binary as a default part of consuming that library. By all means have example scripts, or modules that you can run. But its a library. The programatic API should be very much "the right way" to do it.

None of my use cases are hindered by the presence of the command line API, but I strongly feel that a command line tool that appears in your bin/ dir sends the wrong message, that its the "first class" way to do things. When really the first class way to do it should be via the API.

I think _every_ tool/app/script using pricing data should use the programatic API. I don't see how its any different to wanting a CLI to create a compute node with libcloud.

I don't think that `python -m update.pricing` is any better than `libcloud update-pricing`.  The script by @Kami offers a simple and straightforward solution, however I do understand the concerns raised by @Jc2k.

I don't know the story behind the management CLI @Kami mentioned, but it doesn't sound like a very bad idea. It could be used to update `pricing.json` before each release. By default libcloud would try to get `pricing.json` from SVN and fallback to the local copy. It is a bit more complicated, but if there are more use cases for such a tool, why not. 

Any other ideas?

@Jc2k after more thought, I agree with you. As a first step, I'll merge those the following two changes which allow users to more easily update pricing file.
1. Read pricing from ~/.libcloud/pricing.json file (if available)
2. Programmatic way to update pricing file

I'll leave command line utility for updating the pricing file out for now and work on bootstrapping "libcloud CLI" as a separate package (apache-libcloud-cli). 

First command libcloud-cli will contain will be a command for updating a pricing file.

Sorry for the delay, I totally missed out this PR.

The description says "W.I.P", how far along is it? Is it still recent, can I review it?

Thanks

First some  feedback on the whole approach.
1. I like the explicit route to method mapping in the Brightbox mock. I think we can definitely improve current "implicit" mapping by making all the mappings explicit. Explicit mappings will make writing tests easier and it will also be more obvious to see what is going on.

I think we could make it even better (and less error-prone) if a route would also contain an HTTP method (GET, etc.).
1. I'm not a fan of `_to_json`, `_from_balancer` and other methods. It means we need to keep multiple things in sync (fixtures + those methods). The more things a developer needs to update, the easier it is to forget to update some, which means it more cumbersome and error prone.

I would prefer to stick with just the response fixtures. This way it's easier to maintain and generate the fixtures.

Overall I'm not too sure if I like the "more intelligent" / dynamic mocks approach. It basically means we are re-implementing dummy-like driver and logic for each provider. This has the following disadvantages (imo):
- More things to keep up to date
- It's easier to incorrectly implement a mock
- We are actually just testing the mock API implementation and not the provider API which doesn't add any value imo.

Imo, tests should test the following things:
- Test that each provider method calls the correct provider endpoint
- Test that each method sends the right data (body + query string) along to the endpoint
- Test that data returned by the endpoint is correctly parsed

I would also love to hear other people's opinion.

I agree with you, I think, and you have stated the other half of my internal dialogue quite accurately :-)

I was initially reluctant to stick with the fixtures because we would have to manually update the fixtures to get test data that was consistent enough to allow re-usable tests, but equally effectively requiring devs to implement both sides of the protocol is a bit extreme.

Most of all I want to test that each method is sending the right data. The right arguments. The trouble is, if i parse the entire body all I can do is validate it is a valid request, not that it is the correct request for the arguments that were passed. I can see 2 ways to factor this.

The first is this branch. By "round-tripping" a request I can test that what i put in one end comes out of the other. I must be passing all the data i need to if i can get it back out of the other side.

However i've just thought of a second that fits more naturally with keeping the fixtures. I can create a generic adaptor that records the arguments it was invoked with in a way that lets the mock peek at them, and then calls the driver. I can then parse the incoming body in my mock and make sure it matches the arguments passed to the driver, then return the hard-coded fixture file for that request.

A secondary concern is duplication. If there are 4 variants of the `/balancer/list` API call then it's hard to factor the current mocks to avoid duplicate checking logic. (Is this where you see the route stuff in the Brightbox mock helping?).

As noted in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-384, patch has been merged into trunk.

Thanks, you can close this pull request now.

Thanks.

It would also be great to add some tests as noted in the JIRA ticket.

Otherwise the patch looks good to me and should be ready to be merged once the comments in this PR are addressed.
